question: If individual #1 in the following pedigree <image 1> is a heterozygote for a rare, AR disease, what is the probability that individual #7 will be affected by the disease? Assume that #2 and the spouses of #3 and #4 are not carriers.

- **Inheritance Pattern:**
  - Since individual #1 is a heterozygote (Aa) and individual #2 has two normal alleles (AA), their offspring (#3 and #4) each have a 50% chance of being heterozygotes (Aa) like their mother and a 50% chance of having two normal alleles (AA) like their father.
  - The spouses of #3 and #4 are not carriers (AA), so any children they have with #3 or #4 will inherit at most one disease-causing allele from #3 or #4 if they are heterozygotes.
  - Individual #5, being the child of #3 and a non-carrier spouse, has a 50% chance of being a heterozygote if #3 is a heterozygote.
  - Individual #6, being the child of #4 and a non-carrier spouse, has a 50% chance of being a heterozygote if #4 is a heterozygote.
  - Individual #7, being the offspring of #5 and #6, would need both parents to be heterozygotes (Aa) to have a chance of inheriting the disease. If both #5 and #6 are heterozygotes, there is a 25% chance that #7 will inherit two disease-causing alleles (aa) and be affected by the disease.

This detailed description provides all necessary information to calculate the probability that individual #7 will be affected by the disease based on the given conditions.
